questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about the rhythm method?

options.A: Anencephaly is seen on accidental conception
options.B: It is a cost effective method
options.C: Safe period is determined using temperature or mucous method
options.D: Abstinence is required for 7-10 days in a month

questions.explanation: Anencephaly is not seen in the case of accidental conception in a woman using the rhythmmethod. It occurs due to deficiency of folic acid in the mother.The calendar method or the rhythm method is one of the natural methods of contraception byfertility awareness. The couple is advised avoidance of sexual intercourse around ovulation. Thus,it is very cost-effective but it can only be used by educated couples.According to this method, safe period in a normal 28-day cycle is from the 1st day of menstrualperiod to the 10th day and from the 18th to the 28th day. An alternate method is by calculatingthe risk period i.e., 3 days before and 3 days after ovulation. Ovulation can also be estimated bychanges in cervical mucus and basal body temperature.Another method of calculating the safe period is the Knaus-Ogino method. The fertile period isdetermined by subtracting 18 days from the shortest cycle and 10 days from the longest cycle.This gives the first and the last day of the fertile period, respectively.

questions.question: What does Billing's method of contraception refer to?
questions.explanation: Billing's method of contraception refers to the cervical mucus method. It is also called ovulationmethod.The properties of the cervical mucus change during the menstrual cycle. The female partner canpredict the fertile period by examining her cervical mucus.Under the influence of estrogen, the mucus increases in quantity and becomes more slippery andelastic i.e. wet days. This continues till it reaches a peak. After this, under the influence ofprogesterone, it becomes thicker, scanty i.e. dry days.Abstinence is advised during the wet days till 4 days after the peak day. The safe period includesthe dry days after menses till the appearance of mucus and from the 4th day after the peak day.The pattern of cervical mucus secretion during a menstrual cycle is given below.Billing's cervical mucus method28272625Drydays2423222120SafeMensesMenstruation7SafeBDrydays19UnsafeOvulation18171216151413AbstinencePeakdayMARROW67910Mucussymptomsbegin

questions.question: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image.670
questions.explanation: The given image shows a female condom. It consists of a pouch made of polyurethane which is 17cm in length with a flexible ring at each end. The inner ring at the closed end is smaller than theouter ring.The inner ring is inserted at the apex of the vagina and the outer ring remains outside. It coversthe cervix, the entire vagina, and external genitalia. Hence, it provides protection against HIV andSTDs. It has a failure rate of 5-15 per 100 woman-years, which is higher than that of a malecondom.It can be fitted by the patient hours before intercourse, and easily removed soon after. It coversthe cervix, vagina, and external genitalia and is protective against sexually transmitted diseases. Itcan also be worn in the puerperal period, unlike the cervical diaphragm.The female condom should not be used along with a male condom because if worn together theymay slip, tear, or become displaced.The given image below shows the insertion of a female condom:Insertion of the female condom©MARROW

questions.question: A nulliparous woman has been using Today sponge as a contraceptive. What does thiscontain?
questions.explanation: Today sponge contains 1 g of nonoxynol 9. It is a mushroom-shaped polyurethanedisposable sponge that is 2 inches wide and 1.25 inches thick.It is provided with a loop for easy removal. It should be placed high up in the vagina with theconcave side covering the cervix. It can remain effective for 24 h. It can be used only once.It acts as a mechanical barrier preventing the entry of sperms into the cervical canal, absorbssemen, and contains a spermicidal agent. The failure rate is 9-16 per 100 woman-years.680'Today' vaginal spongeOMARROWW

questions.question: Which of the following is not a contraindication for the use of the contraceptive shownbelow?
questions.explanation: The given image shows a cervical diaphragm or Dutch cap. It can be used by women havingmultiple sex partners.Contraindications of cervical diaphragm usage:•Prolapse, cystocele, rectocele - accurate fitting is not possible•Recurrent urinary tract infection•Allergy to rubber or spermicidal agentIt must be removed following intercourse as it can lead to toxic shock syndrome (TSS) if left in thevagina for a long period. TSS is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcusaureus infection.

questions.question: You are prescribing nonoxynol-9 jelly to a woman using a cervical diaphragm forcontraception. What is its mechanism of action?
questions.explanation: Nonoxynol-9 is one of the spermicidal agents which act by disruption of the sperm cellmembrane.Spermicidal agents are chemical contraceptives as they contain surfactants, such as nonoxynol-9,octoxynol, menfegol and enzyme-inhibiting agents. These are available as:• Foam tablets• Soluble pessaries•Creams• Jellies• Films681The spermicidal agent remains effective for 1-2 hours after the application. They are always usedalong with other contraceptives such as the diaphragm, cervical cap, and condom. When they areused alone, the failure rate is high i.e., 30 per 100 woman-years.Chronic use of spermicides can cause vaginal irritation, abrasion, and ulceration. This increasesthe risk of HIV spread. Hence, spermicidal agents should not be recommended to HIV-positivecouples.

questions.question: A young woman who is using a cervical diaphragm asks for an alternative contraceptive. Yousuggest a recently launched contraceptive Phexxi. What is its composition?

options.A: Lactic acid, Citric Acid, Potassium bitartrate
options.B: Ascorbic acid, Citric acid, Calcium bitartrate
options.C: Lactic acid, Ascorbic acid, Potassium bitartrate
options.D: Ascorbic acid, Lactic acid, Calcium bitartrate.

questions.explanation: Phexxi is a vaginal gel that contains lactic acid, citric acid, and potassium bitartrate.Phexxi is a vaginal pH regulator which is a non-hormonal contraceptive. It works by maintainingvaginal pH within the range of 3.5 to 4.5. This acidic environment is inhospitable for sperms.Phexxi comes in pre-filled vaginal applicators. A single dose must be applied before vaginalintercourse. If more than one act of vaginal intercourse occurs within one hour, an additional dosemust be applied.Phexxi - ApplicatorOMARROW

questions.question: A newly married woman was prescribed Mala-N at a PHC. What is its composition?
questions.explanation: Mala-N is a combined oral contraceptive containing 0.15 mg levonorgestrel (LNG) and 0.03mg ethinyl estradiol. It is supplied free of cost through all PHC's, urban family welfare centers,etc.All combined oral pills contain a mixture of ethinyl estradiol in a dose of 20-30 mcg and an orallyactive progestogen. Mala-D has the same composition as Mala-N but is available at a price of Rs3/- per packet.Combined oral pill works by suppressing pituitary hormones, FSH, and LH peak which preventsovulation. At the same time, progestogen causes atrophic changes in the endometrium and682prevents implantation.Progestogen also acts on the cervical mucus making it thick and tenacious and impenetrable bysperms. It also interferes with tubal motility and alters tubal transport., so the fertilized egg reaches the uterine cavity before the endometrium is receptive forimplantation.These tablets are taken starting on the first day of the cycle for 21 days. A new course of tabletsshould be commenced 7 days after the cessation of the previous course. They should be taken atbedtime, preferably after a meal.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an advantage of norgestimate OCPs?
questions.explanation: Norgestimate is one of the 3rd generation progesterone agents. All OCPs have the disadvantageof increasing the risk of venous thrombosis.Third-generation progesterone agents are less androgenic and so reduce the occurrence of acneand hirsutism. They also have a lower risk of metabolic and cardiovascular disorders compared tothe previous generation progesterone agents.Benefits of combined pills:• Effective contraceptive• Useful in menorrhagia and polymenorrhoea••Relieves dysmenorrhoea and premenstrual tension• Prevents anaemia by reducing the menstrual loss• Lower incidence of benign breast neoplasia (fibrocystic disease), functional ovarian cyst, ovarianand uterine malignancy•Reduced risk of PID - due to thick cervical mucus caused by progestogen, preventing theorganisms from entering into the uterine cavity• Reduced incidence of ectopic pregnancy - due to suppression of ovulation and decreased risk ofPID•Protects against rheumatoid arthritis• Reduces the risk of anorectal cancer• Useful in acne, PCOD, and endometriosis

questions.question: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the use of OCPs?
questions.explanation: Thyroid disorders like hypothyroidism are not a contraindication for OCP usage.Contraindications of OCPS:• Absolute contraindications -• Breast and genital cancers.683• Liver disease• History of thromboembolism•Cardiac abnormalities•Congenital hyperlipidemia•Undiagnosed abnormal uterine bleeding• Relative contraindications -•Age over 40 years, if smoker >35 years• Mild hypertension• Chronic renal disease• Epilepsy• Migraine•First 6 months of breastfeeding• Diabetes mellitus• Gallbladder disease• History of infrequent bleeding or amenorrhea

questions.question: Which of the following drugs do not lead to failure of OCPs?
questions.explanation: Sodium valproate is an inhibitor of CYP enzymes that are responsible for OCP metabolism. Thus,it does not lead to OCP failure.Drugs leading to OCP failure are:• Rifampicin•Tetracyclines - interferes with enterohepatic circulation of estrogen•Phenytoin• Phenobarbitone• Antifungals• Cephalosporin•Ritonavir for HIV - interferes with absorption of OCPMost of the anti-convulsants are enzyme inducers and hence increase the clearance of OCPs. Thisleads to OCP failure.

questions.question: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of progesterone only pills?

options.C: Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

questions.explanation: Minipills or progesterone-only pills (POP) do not kill sperm in the cervical canal.Progesterone-only pills act by thickening the cervical mucus (the main mechanism of all POPS684except cerazette) that inhibits penetration of sperms, inhibiting tubal motility, and suppressingovulation.Other advantages of POPs include a reduction in the incidence of pelvic inflammatory diseasesand sexually transmitted diseases (due to thickened cervical mucus).Due to the inhibition of tubal motility, the absolute risk of all pregnancies including ectopicpregnancy decreases, while the relative risk of ectopic pregnancy increases. But a previous historyof ectopic pregnancy is not a contraindication for POP.POPS do not affect clotting, lipid metabolism, and carbohydrate metabolism. So they can safely beused by women who are obese, breastfeeding, hypertensive, have SLE or a history ofthromboembolism, diabetic with vascular disease. Significant adverse effects of POPs are irregularbleeding (mostly scanty), and secondary amenorrhea after longtime usage as it causes endometrialatrophy.Contraindications for POPS include undiagnosed vaginal bleeding, pregnancy, known or suspectedbreast cancer, and benign or malignant liver tumors.

questions.question: A patient has come to your clinic for contraceptive advice. As she has a family history ofbreast cancer, you suggest a non-hormonal oral contraceptive to her. What is the initial doseof this drug?
questions.explanation: Centchroman is a non-hormonal oral contraceptive that is started at a dose of 30 mg on the firstday of the menstrual cycle. It can be given to women with a family history of breast cancer wherehormonal contraceptives are contraindicated.Centchroman or ormeloxifene is a synthetic nonsteroidal contraceptive. Following the initial doseof 30 mg on the first day of menses, it is taken twice weekly for 12 weeks and weekly thereafter. Itprevents implantation through endometrial changes. The return of fertility occurs within 6months of stopping the drug.It can also be used as a postcoital pill, given in 60 mg dose within 24 hours of coitus. It has afailure rate of 1.83 per 100 woman years. It does not provide protection against HIV and otherSTDs.Side effects of centchroman:Headache, nausea, vomiting• Weight gain•Delay in return of fertility (up to 6 months)• Atypical endometrial hyperplasia - prolonged useContraindications of centchroman:• PCOD• Hepatic dysfunction•Cervical dysplasia•Allergy to the drugThis drug has been developed by Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow. It has been releasedin India under the name of Chhaya (previously called Saheli) under the National Family Planning685Programme.Centchroman Tablets I.P8 TabletsFor Government of IndiaSupply onlyChhayaNon-Steroidal Oral Contraceptive PilOnce a Weeksasha

questions.question: Which of the following is the most effective reversible method of contraception?
questions.explanation: The most effective reversible method of contraception among the given options is Norplant, whichis a subdermal hormonal implant.The most effective method of contraception overall is sterilization, which is one of the permamentmethods. Both methods belong to the first-tier category of contraceptives.There are 2 types of subdermal implants:•Implanon (which has replaced Norplant I)•Norplant IIThe implants work by inhibition of ovulation, endometrial atrophy, and thickening of cervicalmucus. Implanon contains desogestrel and also reduces acne and osteoporosis.The implants are inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, and 3weeks after the delivery. The woman needs to use barrier contraception or abstain in the first 7days of insertion.The image below shows an implanon:686123456L8610ELLThe image given below shows the insertion of a subdermal implant:Advantages of implants:•Long-acting with sustained effect••• Good complianceCoital-independent with no nuisance of daily oral or frequent injections•Failure rate -0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman-years• Implanon reduces acne and osteoporosis.Disadvantages of implants:•Breakthrough bleeding•• Irregular cycles687• Amenorrhoea•Ectopic pregnancy• Local infectionRequires insertion and removal with nonbiodegradable capsules• Expensive.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of the device given in the image below?234 5 6 7 8
questions.explanation: The given image shows Multiload Cu250, which is one of the copper containing IUCDs. Formationof cervical mucus plug is not one of its mechanisms of action. However, progesterone-containingIUCDs can alter the cervical mucus along with the local effects.The various mechanisms of action of a copper-containing IUCD are:• Interference with the migration of spermatozoa• Foreign body reaction releasing prostaglandins - provokes uterine contractility and increases thetubal peristalsis which interferes with implantation• Leucocytic infiltration in the endometrium - macrophages engulf the fertilized egg if it enters theendometrial tissue•• Enzymatic and metabolic changes in the endometrial tissue which interferes with implantationof the fertilized ovumSome IUCDs like CuT-380A are effective for up to 10 years.They are a good choice of method of contraception for the following groups of women:• Having low risk of STD• Multiparous woman• Having a monogamous relationship•Wanting long-term reversible method of contraception•Unreliable users of oral contraception or barrier contraceptionIUCDs are avoided in unmarried and nulliparous patients because of the risk of PID andsubsequent tubal infertility. Copper IUCDs can also be used as emergency contraception followingintercourse.

questions.question: 674IUCD insertion is being considered in a multiparous woman who wants long-termcontraception. This method of contraception is absolutely contraindicated in all of thefollowing except
questions.explanation: IUCDs can be used in HIV-affected women.Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) provide long-term contraception by preventingfertilization.Contraindications for IUCD insertion:688•Suspected pregnancy• Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)•• Lower genital tract infection• Presence of fibroids• Severe anaemia• Uncontrolled diabetes - due to increased pelvic infection•Scarred uterus eg, post caesarean section•Septate uterus• Menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea - if Copper T is used• Breast cancer if LNG IUCD is used-Complications of IUCD usage:• Immediate -•• Vasovagal attack• Uterine cramps• Early-• Expulsion of IUCD●• Perforation of uterus• Spotting, menorrhagia•• Dysmenorrhoea• Vaginal infection•⚫ Actinomycosis•• Late -•• PID•Ectopic pregnancy• Perforation of uterus• Menorrhagia• DysmenorrhoeaThe failure rate of IUCD is 1-3 per 100 woman-years.Levonorgestrel IUCD also causes hormonal adverse effects such as headache, acne, breasttenderness, and functional ovarian cysts. Amenorrhoea occurs in 35% of women after 2 years ofuse.

questions.question: A nursing mother was prescribed progestasert for contraception. How much progesterone isreleased by this device?
questions.explanation: Progestasert releases 65 µg of progesterone/day.Progestasert is a T-shaped device carrying 38 mg of progesterone in a silicon oil reservoir in thevertical stem. The progesterone released causes the formation of a thick plug of mucus at thecervical os. This prevents entry of the sperms in addition to the local contraceptive effect ofIUCDs.There is lesser incidence of menstrual problems like menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea comparedto copper-containing intrauterine devices. However, it is expensive and requires yearlyreplacement.

questions.question: Which of the following increases the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease?
questions.explanation: Copper IUCDs increase the risk of PID.OCPs, Mirena and DMPA injectables contain progesterone which causes thickening of the cervicalmucus and decreases the motility of the female genital tract. Thus, they reduce the risk of PID bypreventing the ascent of bacteria from the vagina.

questions.question: What is the most effective mode of contraception for a woman with heart disease?
questions.explanation: IUCDs are the most effective mode of contraception for women with heart diseases. IUCDs aresafe in these patients and come under the first-tier contraceptive methods.Condoms are not contraindicated in heart disease patients but they are third-tier contraceptives.Hence, they are not as effective as IUCDs.691OCPs and hormonal implants are contraindicated in patients with heart diseases as theconstituent hormones can cause thromboembolic disorders.

questions.question: Which of the following techniques of permanent contraception does not require an abdominalincision?
questions.explanation: Essure permanent device is a method of hysteroscopic sterilization. Pomeroy, Parkland, andIrving procedures are methods for tubal ligation via an abdominal approach.Essure device consists of a micro-inserter with a flexible inner coil made of stainless steel and adynamic outer coil made of nickel titanium alloy (nitinol).This device is inserted into the fallopian tube by hysteroscopy. It acts by benign local fibroustissue growth leading to occlusion of the tube. The failure rate is 3.5%.Its advantages are that there is no abdominal scar and the procedure can be done under localanaesthesia.Disadvantages of Essure:•Hysteroscopy required for the procedure and to confirm the blockage• Expensive procedure•Expertise required• Irreversible tuboplasty for reversal not possible-• 3 months waiting time to ensure sterility - HSG must be done after 3 months to confirm tubalblockage• Bilateral insertion difficult due to spasm• Can cause perforation of the tubeEssure deviceScar tissue growsinto the Essure deviceOMARROWFallopian tubeEssure device692

questions.question: A woman has come to your clinic for a checkup following tubal ligation by Pomeroytechnique. Which portion of the tube is ligated in this technique?
questions.explanation: Isthmus of the fallopian tube is ligated in Pomeroy technique. It is the most popular technique oftubal ligation.Midline, paramedian or transverse abdominal incision is made 2 inches above the pubicsymphysis (1 inch in puerperal sterilisation). The fallopian tube is identified, made into a loop andtied at the base. The loop is then excised.The operation is simple and requires a short period of hospitalization. The failure rate is only0.4% and it is mainly due to spontaneous canalization. It is surgically reversible.The below image shows Pomeroy's method of tubal ligation.Pomeroy's method of tubectomyMA segment of the fallopian tube is lifted up.MLoop (mainly isthmus and part of the ampulla)is ligated with chromic catout at the base and is cut.Healed tubal stumps resulting in wide separation.OMARROW

questions.question: Fimbriectomy is also known as:
questions.explanation: Fimbriectomy is also known as Kroener's procedure. This procedure involves ligation of the distalampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures. Then, resection of the infundibulum of the tubeis done.693Fimbriectomy©MARROWSome more techniques of permanent sterilization include:Pomeroy method - The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision.The middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised. This isthe most commonly used technique.PomeroyOMARROWUchida's method - The tubal serosa is stripped off the muscular layer in the midsegment of thetube. The muscle layer is excised. The proximal end is ligated and buried in the broad ligament.This minimal excision of the tube preserves the potential for tuboplasty.694Uchida techniqueMADMOOMARROWIrving's procedure - The mid-portion of the tube is ligated and the intervening portion is excised.The proximal end is buried in the myometrium and the distal end is buried in the broad ligament.It is a reliable method but irreversible and may require a laparotomy incision.Irving procedureMOMARROWMadlener's procedure - A loop of the fallopian tube is crushed and then ligated with anonabsorbable suture.695Madlener procedureOMARROW

questions.question: A 40-year-old male patient underwent a vasectomy. What is the failure rate of thisprocedure?
questions.explanation: The failure rate of vasectomy is 0.15%This procedure is done under local anaesthesia. A small incision is made in the scrotum. The vasdeferens are divided on both sides which disrupts the passage of sperms.The no-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with special forcepsand skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting.The sperms can remain in the reproductive tract for up to 3 months. Hence, sterility is notimmediate. The couple must abstain from intercourse during this period or use other methods ofcontraception.Approximately, 20 ejaculates clear the semen of all sperms. Two semen analysis reports mustconfirm the absence of sperms before the man can be declared sterile.BladderSeminalvesiclesProstateVas deferensVasectomyUrethra-TestisOMARROWEpididymis696

questions.question: A couple with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse requires emergency contraception.Which of the following is not a mechanism by which these drugs act?

options.C: Preventing the implantation of the fertilized egg

questions.explanation: Emergency contraceptives do not interrupt early pregnancy, once conception has occured. Theyare used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse. Hence, they are alsocalled interceptives.The main action of emergency contraceptives is to make the endometrium unsuitable forimplantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation, and prevent fertilization of the egg bysperms.Methods of emergency contraception:DrugLevonorgestrelEthinyl estradiol 50 μg + Norgestrel 0.25 mgRU486 (Mifepristone)Ethinyl EstradiolCopper IUDsCentchromanUlipristalDose0.75mg stat and repeat doseafter 12 hours or1.5mg as a single dose2 tabs stat and 2 tabs after 12hoursSingle dose of 25-50mg2.5 mg BD X 5 daysInsertion within 5 days of intercourse2 tabs(60 mg) to be taken twice at an interval of 12 hoursShould be taken within 24 hours of intercourse.30 mg within 5 days of intercourse

questions.question: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of unprotected intercourse 2 days ago.Which of the following will you prescribe as a single dose contraceptive?
questions.explanation: Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg can be used as a single dose emergencycontraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.Alternatively, one tablet of LNG 0.75mg can be followed by another tablet 12 hours later. Thetablets can be offered up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the increase in intervalbetween coitus and drug intake.LNG prevents ovulation and makes endometrium unsuitable for implantation. The failure rate is1.1%. If pregnancy occurs as a result of contraceptive failure, the risk of ectopic pregnancyincreases but it is not teratogenic.Advantages of LNG:• No oestrogen and its associated side effects697• Can be used in hypertensive, cardiac and diabetic patients• Suitable for lactating woman• Can be given up to 120 hours after the unprotected intercourse•Single-dose therapyContraindications of LNG:• Liver disease•Thrombophlebitis•Migraine• Galactose allergy - as the tablet contains lactose
